climbs.name: You Ain't Nothing but a Corndog
climbs.fa: Jarrod Webb and Mark Randall and Kaolin Young 5/2020

content.description: Climb water streak past 4 bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location: 3rd bolt line from the left on the cliff.

climbs.name: The Velveteen Corndog
climbs.fa: Kevin Keith and David Scalia January 2020

content.description: Climb an arete out of the trees placing gear up to a single bolt and the crux. A chain anchor awaits you on a tiny ledge prior to the summit.
content.protection: Gear to #3 camalot and a bolt.
content.location: Arete out of the trees on the right side of the wall

content.description: This is a TR problem that exits a steep roof and pulls up to a horizontal. The route can finish several ways. Should have bolts soon however rock is suspect to hold good bolts at the lip so....we shall see.
content.location: Big chalky hold on right side of route gives it away.

content.description: Face climb up the black holds to a ledge, continue up and right to gain another sloping ledge. The bolt at the crux is in hollow sounding rock. Chain anchor at the top.
Boulder up past a few bolts and enter the unprotected squeeze chimney up high. A bolted anchor without chains is high up on the right.
content.location: 9th route from the left, obvious bolts to a shallow chimney.

content.description: Boulder up past a couple of bolts and move left up high to two more bolts before the anchor.

climbs.name: The Girl with the Corndog Tattoo

content.description: Bouldery start, fun face climbing, 3 bolts, chain anchor up high.

climbs.name: Full Metal Corndog
climbs.fa: Jarrod Webb, Mark Randall, Kevin Keith 4/2020

content.description: Step up on the left side of a waist high shelf and fight your way up positive holds past 4 bolts to reach the chain anchor.
Face climbing up a low angle chute past 3 bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location: Furthest left route on the wall.

climbs.name: Flight of the Corndogs
climbs.fa: Several on TR until cleaned. J Webb bolted and Andrew Zapushek was first to lead  1/2021

content.description: Boulder through a gritty roof to a steep face. Place a cam or two and move up to gain the steep shallow corner chute like feature. Bolts protect the upper section.
content.protection: bolts and gear #1,2 or 3 camalots it looks like.
content.location: Middle of Wall with roof start and another bulge to enter a chute. Pretty obvious.

content.description: Weird bouldery start leads to "funner" slab climbing above.

climbs.name: Cornish Gamedog
climbs.fa: Kevin Keith and David Scalia January 2020

content.description: Fun bouldery start which is the v0+ crux, then 5.6 climbing to a chain anchor.
content.location: Just right of the head high roof on right side of the wall

content.description: Wow this route is really cool for the area. Tricky start, thin reachy crux and a sweet technical exit. Are you not entertained!!
Climb up right side of waist high shelf and face climb past 5 bolts to a chain anchor.

climbs.name: Butch Cassidy and the Corndog Kid
climbs.fa: Andrew Zapushek, Jarrod Webb, Wayne Augusto 5/2020

content.description: Tricky bouldering past two bolts then move left to gain a crack in a v slot. Work upward to a ledge past another bolt and the anchor.
content.protection: Gear to #2 camalot and a few draws
content.location: 7th route from the left, this is an obvious feature

content.description: There are a couple of ways to climb this obvious chimney like feature on the far right side of the Corndog Wall

climbs.name: A Corndog Named Desire
climbs.fa: Kevin Keith and David Scalia January 2020

content.description: Tricky start followed by sustained climbing in a shallow corner. Several exit options exist.
content.location: on the right side of the wall in the treed area.

content.description: The Corndog Wall is a 30' wall along the north side of the Stairway Loop trail. The majority of the routes are bolted and range from 5.5 to 5.11 currently. The rock is coarse and getting better with time. Many of the routes have seen few ascents so bear in mind that we are still in the break in phase. It is imperative that climbers are mindful of hikers and keep the trail free of gear and pets. This area has been in the back of our mind for years while we worked on taller routes in the vicinity. Eventually we all came around to the idea of a quick hit sport climbing area that was easy to access and quick to climb. Jarrod Webb led the charge on the basic outline of the routes and especially the Corndog theme. I think years of gas station corndogs finally took their toll. If you meet him thank him for his hard work, hell... buy him a corndog
